bestBHT.bht: If the collection is large enough to be considered worthy of the apostle's journey, then the apostle will accompany them instead of just providing letters of recommendation. This would not be for security or to ensure a warm reception, but rather to carry the collection with the dignity of an apostolic mission. By going together, any suspicions of wrongdoing can be avoided, and the apostle's commitment to the cause can be demonstrated.

Henry Alford: But if it (the occasion,—dependent on the magnitude of your collection) be worthy of my also taking the journey..."

if your collection be large enough to warrant an apostolic mission, in order to carry it—not said for security, nor to procure himself a fair reception at Jerusalem,—but with the sense of the dignity of an apostolic mission
This did apparently take place, see Acts xx. 4 ff.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: If your collections be large enough to be worth an apostle's journey (a stimulus to their liberality), I will accompany them myself instead of giving them letters credential.
With me—to guard against all possible suspicion of evil.
Albert Barnes: If it be judged desirable and best.
If my presence can further the object; or will satisfy you better; or will be deemed necessary to guide and aid those who may be sent, I will be willing to go also.

For some appropriate and valuable remarks in regard to the apostle Paul's management of pecuniary matters, so as not to excite suspicion, and to preserve a blameless reputation, see Paley's Horae Paulinae, chapter iv. No. 1, 3. Note.
Marvin Vincent: Meet for me to go, if it be worthy of my going, i.e., if the gift be sufficiently large to warrant an apostolic journey to Jerusalem.
If it be worthy of my going, i.e., if the gift be sufficiently large to warrant an apostolic journey to Jerusalem.
This is better than if it be becoming.
Archibald T. Robertson: If the collection be worthy of the going as to me also.
Condition of third class and the articular infinitive in the genitive.
The accusative of general reference with the infinitive.
John Gill: If it should be convenient for me to go...that is, their beneficence; if so large a collection should be made, that it will be worthy of an apostle to go along with it."
...he would not go alone, nor propose it, to remove all suspicion of converting any money to his own use.
John Wesley: They shall go with me — To remove any possible suspicion.

bhtAttempts.bht: If the collection of funds is significant enough to warrant an apostolic journey to Jerusalem, then it is fitting and worthy for the apostle to accompany them instead of just providing letters of recommendation. This would not be for the sake of security or a favorable reception, but rather to uphold the dignity and importance of the mission. It is also mentioned that this did indeed take place in Acts. By going together, it would guard against any suspicions of wrongdoing and demonstrate the apostle's commitment to the cause.

If the collection is large enough to warrant an apostolic journey, the apostle will accompany them instead of providing letters of recommendation, to uphold the dignity of the mission. This would be to guard against any suspicions of wrongdoing and demonstrate commitment to the cause. By going together, it would show that the collection is worthy of an apostle's involvement and further support the object.

If the occasion calls for it and the collection is sufficient in magnitude, the apostle will take the journey and accompany them. This is not for the sake of security or personal reception, but rather to carry the collection with the dignity of an apostolic mission. The apostle's presence would guard against any possible suspicion of evil. By going together, it would demonstrate the worthiness of the collection and the apostle's commitment to support and guide them.

If the collection is large enough to be considered worthy of the apostle's journey, then the apostle will accompany them instead of just providing letters of recommendation. This would not be for security or to ensure a warm reception, but rather to carry the collection with the dignity of an apostolic mission. By going together, any suspicions of wrongdoing can be avoided, and the apostle's commitment to the cause can be demonstrated.

If the collection is worthy of an apostolic journey, it is fitting for the apostle to accompany them instead of just providing letters of credential. This would not be for the sake of security or a favorable reception, but with the sense of the dignity of an apostolic mission. By going together, it would guard against all possible suspicion of evil.
